Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: NVM-enabled Host-side Caches

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-volatile memory (NVM) is a transformative technology that is dramatically changing how data storage systems of the
future are built. This technology allows an unprecedented combination of performance and persistence into a single
device. This project will develop a suite of storage caching techniques for this transformative technology along four
complementary dimensions.

The first two usage dimensions address the selective use of NVM as host-side read caches for persistently stored data
as well as using their persistence properties explicitly by developing fault-tolerant write caching solutions. The
latter two develop advanced techniques for delivering storage quality of service (QoS) using NVM caches and building caching
algorithms that are aware of data reduction techniques, such as deduplication and compression, for the NVM layer. Together, these contributions have the potential to transform enterprise data center storage stacks by readily adopting the best properties of current and future NVM technology. The expected performance benefits apply to a broad spectrum of computer systems and applications.

Educational activities will include the involvement of undergraduate students and incorporation of the project's research findings into coursework. Planned outreach activities will focus on recruitment of under-represented students from minority groups in computer science for participation in the project. Transition of the new technologies to practice through open source distribution of the Linux operating system and KVM hypervisor code implementing the innovations are successful expectations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: 

We developed and evaluated multiple approaches and associated implementations of NVM-enabled host-side caches. We evaluated these implementations with both synthetic and real-world workloads. Such caches are widely used by enterprise and cloud systems today. Our work was deeply grounded in the insight derived from data-driven analysis of production storage workloads from multiple enterprise and cloud systems. 
The developed and evaluated systems included LeCar, ALeCar, and Cacheus, new ML-based caching algorithms that evolved sequentially. We demonstrate that the latest evolution, Cacheus, outperforms the state-of-the-art across across over 16,000 different combinations of workloads and cache configurations with statistical significance. We proved that the new non-datapath caching algorithms that we developed have provable theoretical performance for the cache replacement problem.  We also developed mOPT, a theoretically optimal non-datapath caching algorithm as well as m*, FOMO, and ANX, three new non-datapath caching algorithms that address the needs of NVM-based non-datapath caches. These algorithms allow striking the necessary balance between cache performance and cache lifetime. We studied new consistency model for optimizing host-side metadata caches in distributed file systems and developed HasFS, a new file system design for DRAM-NVM-Disk storage architecture that optimizes the periodic "sync" operations to slow storage. Finally, we also built Simulus, a generic python simulator for large-scale complex systems such as host-side and distributed caching systems. 

Broader impact: 

Storage I/O performance is central to the functioning of high-performance software systems and the services infrastructure in enterprise and cloud data centers that drive the Internet. Datapath and non-datapath caches represent fundamental building blocks for making storage more performant and cost-efficient. The contributions of this project thus impact state-of-the-art computing technology and computing infrastructure. 
This project supported five Hispanic PhD students, three female PhD students, as well as four Hispanic undergraduate students, and two female undergraduate students over the duration of the project via REU supplements. 

Outcomes summary:

The findings from this project significantly advance the development of next generation enterprise and cloud systems by allowing for significantly more flexible cost-performance trade-offs than their predecessors.
